raw_text:
Mixed Christmas for US retailers
 
 US retailers posted mixed results for December - with luxury retailers faring well while many others were forced to slash prices to lift sales.
 
 Upscale department store Nordstrom said same store sales were 9.3% higher than during the same period last year. Trendy youth labels also sold well, with sales jumping 28% at young women's clothing retailer Bebe Stores and 32.2% at American Eagle Outfitters. But Wal-Mart only saw its sales rise after it cut prices. The company saw a 3% rise in December sales, less than the 4.3% rise seen a year earlier.
 
 Customers at the world's biggest retailer are generally seen to be the most vulnerable to America's economic woes.
 
 Commentators claim many have cut back on spending amid uncertainty over job security, while low and middle-income Americans have reined in spending in the face of higher gasoline prices. Analysts said Wal-Mart faced a "stand-off" with shoppers, stepping up its discounts as the festive season wore on, as consumers waited longer to get the best bargains. However, experts added that if prices had not been cut across the sector, Christmas sales - which account for nearly 23% of annual retail sales - would have been far worse. "So far, we are faring better than expected, but the results are still split," Ken Perkins, an analyst at research firm RetailMetrics LLC, told Associated Press. "Stores that have been struggling over the last couple of months appear to be continuing that trend. And for stores that have been doing well over the last several months, December was a good month." Overall, December sales are forecast to rise by 4.5% to $220bn - less than the 5.1% increase seen a year earlier.
 
 One discount retailer to fare well in December was Costco Wholesale, which continued a recent run of upbeat results with a better-than-expected 8% jump in same store sales. However, the losers were many and varied. Home furnishings store Pier 1 Imports saw its same store sales sink by a larger-than-forecast 8.8% as it battled fierce competition. Leading electronics chain Best Buy, meanwhile, missed its sales target of a 3-5% rise in sales, turning in a 2.5% increase over the Christmas period. Accessory vendor Claire's Stores also suffered as an expected last minute shopping rush never materialised, leaving its same store sales 5% higher, compared to a 6% rise last year. Jeweller Zale also felt little Christmas cheer with December sales down 0.7% on the same month last year. "This was not a good period for retailers or shoppers. We saw a dearth of exciting, new items," Kurt Barnard, president of industry forecaster Retail Consulting Group, said. However, one beneficiary of the desertion of the High Street is expected to be online stores. According to a survey by Goldman Sachs & Co, Harris Interactive and Neilsen/Net Ratings sales surged 25% over the holiday season to $23.2bn.
llama3.2:1b: US retailers posted mixed results for December with luxury retailers doing well while others struggled due to price cuts.
Nordstrom saw an 9.3% increase in same-store sales, Bebe and American Eagle Outfitters also showed a strong performance.
Wal-Mart increased its sales by 3%, less than the year before.
Customers are vulnerable to economic woes but tend to cut back on spending during uncertain times.
Retailers faced challenges due to lower gasoline prices and uncertainty over job security for some customers.
The Christmas season saw nearly 23% of annual retail sales, with Wal-Mart's forecasted rise at 4.5%.
llama3.2:3b: US retailers had mixed results in December with luxury retailers performing well but many others cutting prices.
Nordstrom saw 9.3% higher same-store sales while Bebe Stores and American Eagle Outfitters jumped by 28% and 32.2%, respectively.
Walmart's sales rose only after it cut prices, while customers at the company faced an "economic woes" led to reduced spending.
Costco Wholesale saw a 8% jump in same-store sales, but many retailers, including Best Buy and Pier 1 Imports, missed their sales targets.
Online stores benefited from the decline of brick-and-mortar retailers, with sales surging by 25%.
gemma2:2b: US retailers had mixed results for December, with luxury retailers performing well while many others had to cut prices to boost sales.
Wal-Mart saw a 3% rise in sales after price cuts, while upscale stores like Nordstrom and Bebe Stores experienced significant gains.
However, many other retailers, including Pier 1 Imports, Best Buy, and Claire's, struggled with declining sales.
Costco Wholesale showed strong results, and online shopping experienced a surge in sales during the holiday season.
Overall, December sales are projected to rise but remain below last year's performance.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Here's a summary of the text:

- US retailers posted mixed results for December, with some improving (e.g., Nordstrom), while others saw sales decline.
- Upscale department store Nordstrom reported an upward trend in sales.
- Trendy youth labels had a good month, seeing sales increase at Bebe Stores and American Eagle Outfitters.
- Wal-Mart faced a stand-off from customers, reducing prices as the holiday season approached.
Sales rose 3% compared to a year earlier.
- Overall, December sales are forecast to rise by 4.5%, down 2.8% year-over-year in the UK but up 10.7% in America.
qwen2.5:1.5b: US retailers experienced mixed Christmas results: luxury brands like Nordstrom posted strong growth while many others saw declines due to low sales and price cuts by Walmart.
High-end electronics chain Best Buy missed its goal, while other stores struggled as consumers shopped online instead of in physical malls.
Overall, December sales are forecast to rise by 4.5%, less than a year earlier.
qwen2.5:3b: US retailers reported mixed results for December, with luxury brands doing well while many others struggled due to price cuts.
Nordstrom saw a strong 9.3% increase in same-store sales, and Bebe Stores also experienced significant growth at young women's clothing stores.
American Eagle Outfitters followed suit with a 32.2% jump.
In contrast, Walmart only managed a 3% rise, largely due to cutting prices.
Analysts noted that many shoppers cut back on spending amid economic uncertainty, leading to more discounts from retailers like Wal-Mart.
Costco Wholesale performed well at 8%, while Pier 1 Imports saw a larger-than-expected decline of 8.8%.
Best Buy and Claire's Stores also struggled with sales growth below expectations.
Zale reported a slight drop in sales, attributing it to no significant last-minute shopping rush.
The holiday season still provided some financial benefit for online stores, as indicated by a 25% increase in sales from the survey of Goldman Sachs & Co, Harris Interactive, and Nielsen/Net Ratings.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: During December, US retailers reported mixed performance: luxury brands saw strong gains, while others struggled with pricing cuts.
Key players included Nordstrom with 9.3% growth, Bebe Stores 28%, American Eagle Outfitters 32%.
Wal-Mart fell short due to price cuts.
Overall, retail sales rose by ~4.5% in December but were lower than the previous year.
High street stores faced a shortage of new products, while online retailers like Amazon showed strong growth.
Low-income consumers were spending less due to fuel costs.
tinyllama:1.1b: In the US retail industry for December, luxury retailers such as Nordstrom outperformed their peers despite falling prices and high levels of consumer uncertainty, while department stores BeBe's and American Eagle Outfitters posted strong sales growth due to better pricing.
Meanwhile, Walmart faced a "stand-off" with its customers over discounts in the face of higher gasoline prices.
However, for retailers struggling to meet the festive season, Christmas sales were overall split, with shoppers choosing to spend less as consumer uncertainty persisted.
Many low-income and middle-class consumers were also stepping back from spending, resulting in lower sales across the retail sector.
However, online stores saw an increase of 25% over the holiday season, according to a survey by Goldman Sachs & Co, Harris Interactive, and Neilsen/Net Ratings.
tinydolphin:1.1b: US retailers faced mixed results for December - with luxury retailers faring well while many others were forced to cut prices to lift sales.

Luxury retailers, such as Nordstrom and young women's clothing labels Bebe Stores, saw their same store sales rise 9.3% higher than during the same period last year, while trendy youth brands like American Eagle Outfitters also saw a 28% increase in sales, according to data from Nordstrom.
The company reported that its sales rose by 3%, well below the 4.3% rise seen a year earlier.
phi:2.7b: US retailers had mixed results for December with luxury retailers doing well while others had to slash prices to boost sales.
Nordstrom reported 9.3% higher same store sales than last year, while Bebe Stores and American Eagle Outfitters saw a 28% and 32.2% increase in sales respectively.
Wal-Mart's sales only rose after it cut prices, with a 3% rise compared to 4.3% last year.
Customers at the world's biggest retailer are generally seen as vulnerable to America's economic woes.
Retail analysts say many have cut back on spending due to job security concerns and rising gasoline prices, while low and middle-income Americans have reduced their spending.
Discount retailers like Costco Wholesale did well in December, while companies like Pier 1 Imports and Best Buy saw a decline in sales.
Claire's Stores and Zale also experienced weaker performance.
Online stores are expected to benefit from the decline of traditional retail.
Goldman Sachs surveyed retailers and found that online sales surged by 25% over the holiday season.
orca-mini:3b: US retailers reported mixed results for December with upscale department store Nordstrom saying same store sales were 9.3% higher than last year, while trendy youth labels also saw strong sales, with Bebe Stores up 28% and American Eagle Outfitters jumping 32.2%.
However, Wal-Mart only saw its sales rise after it cut prices, indicating that customers were cautious with their spending due to uncertainty over job security and higher gasoline prices.

Discount retailers such as Costco Wholesale fared well while home furnishings store Pier 1 Imports saw a 8.8% drop in same store sales, while electronics chain Best Buy missed its sales target of a 3-5% rise in sales and Claire's Stores also suffered due to a lack of last minute shopping rush.
Jeweller Zale also reported lower sales during the festive period.
However, online stores saw a surge in sales during the holiday season, with Goldman Sachs & Co reporting a 25% increase in sales over the period.
hermes3:3b: US retailers have mixed Dec results; luxury retailers (Nordstrom) do well, while many others cut prices to boost sales.
Overall, December sales are forecast to rise by 4.5%.

Discount retailer Costco Wholesale fared better, posting an 8% increase in same-store sales.
Many traditional retailers, however, suffered, including Home Furnishings store Pier 1 Imports and electronics chain Best Buy.
Online stores are expected to benefit from the struggles of High Street retailers.
chatgpt-4o-latest: US retailers experienced mixed results in December, with luxury and trendy youth brands performing well while others struggled.
Nordstrom saw a 9.3% sales increase, and American Eagle Outfitters and Bebe Stores posted strong gains.
However, Wal-Mart's sales rose only 3% after price cuts, reflecting economic concerns among low and middle-income shoppers.
Analysts noted that discounts helped prevent worse results, with overall December sales expected to rise 4.5% to $220bn, lower than the previous year's 5.1% increase.
Costco performed well with an 8% sales jump, but retailers like Pier 1 Imports, Best Buy, Claire’s Stores, and Zale saw weaker-than-expected results.
Analysts cited a lack of exciting new products as a factor.
Meanwhile, online sales surged 25% to $23.2bn, benefiting from shifting consumer preferences.
stablelm2:1.6b: US retailers had mixed results in December due to varying performances among luxury and mainstream retailers.
Nordstrom reported an 9.3% increase in same store sales while Bebe Stores saw a 10% rise, while American Eagle Outfitters experienced only a 2% jump.
However, Walmart saw no significant growth after they cut prices.

Most customers are affected by economic issues, and analysts predict that if discounts weren e not provided across the sector, Christmas sales would have been much worse with an estimated decrease of up to 10%.
December sales are forecasted to rise by 4.5% to $2 billion - less than last year's 5.1%.
Costco continued a good run of performance with an 8% jump in same store sales; however, stores like Pier 1 Imports and Best Buy encountered significant declines.
Accessory vendors and jewelers also experienced negative growth.
Online stores reportedly had increased sales during the holiday season.
granite3.1-dense:2b: US retailers reported mixed performance during December, with luxury and upscale departments thriving while budget-conscious consumers drove down prices for broader retailers like Wal-Mart.
Nordstrom saw 9.3% higher same-store sales, while youth labels Bebe Stores and American Eagle Outfitters reported significant sales increases (28% and 32.2%, respectively).
However, Wal-Mart's sales rose only marginally (3%) due to aggressive discounting amid consumer price sensitivity.
Wal-Mart, often considered the most vulnerable to economic strains, faced a "stand-off" with frugal shoppers as they waited for better deals.
Without deep discounts, Christmas sales could have been much worse.
Overall, December retail sales are projected to increase by 4.5% ($220 billion) compared to the previous year (5.1%).
Costco Wholesale, a discount retailer, managed an impressive 8% same-store sales growth.
Yet, Pier 1 Imports faced a substantial 8.8% decline in same-store sales due to competitive pressures.
Best Buy missed its target (3-5%) with a mere 2.5% increase, and Claire's Stores saw a 5% rise, down from last year's 6%.
Jeweler Zale's December sales dropped by 0.7%, indicating disappointing results for many retailers.
Despite mixed outcomes, online retail is expected to gain ground as brick-and-mortar struggles continue.
According to a Goldman Sachs survey, holiday season sales surged 25% to $23.2 billion among internet-based stores.
